title: Kapiti Island
description: Predator-free sanctuary with native wildlife, walking trails, and stunning views — the journey with the boat is an adventure in itself. Beware of the cheeky weka and kaka birds!

ratingNegative.text: i went there and was instantly jumped by a hoard of angry seals
ratingNegative.author: Matheo Sharp

ratingPositive.text: It is a nice looking island I love it when you are playing in the sand 😀😉 Go to beach now.have a great stay.!
ratingPositive.author: Josh Humphreys

attribution: Geoff McKay from Palmerston North, New Zealand, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Blue Penguins Pukekura
description: Watch the world's smallest penguins return to shore at dusk in; this is an almost guaranteed sighting. Pro tip: Do not run to the front of the viewing platform, as the penguins will walk by on the left, giving you a much better and longer view.

ratingNegative.text: They restrict the access to the beach. Not possible to see without a tour. Tourist trap!
ratingNegative.author: Mikhail Grevtsov

ratingPositive.text: They’re impossibly cute, like tiny plush toys come to life, and you can often hear them under the platform you’re standing on even if you can’t see them.
ratingPositive.author: Luthien E.

title: Chameleon Stargazing Tour
description: Take the opportunity to enjoy some guided stargazing with this tour at Lake Tekapo. Savor hot chocolate, cozy blankets, and roasted marshmallows under the night sky. Listen to enchanting stories and fascinating facts about the celestial wonders from your guide.

ratingNegative.text: We brought our 18-month-old child, and the stargazing guide rudely informed us that the child was too noisy and we'd be “kicked off” the bus. I feel this unfriendly attitude toward children really needs improvement. Roasting marshmallows was also boring.
ratingNegative.author: Zila. S

ratingPositive.text: GODDESS STARGAZING EXPERIENCE What a stunning experience with our two fabulous stargazing guides.
ratingPositive.author: Jocelyn Oades

title: Rotorua Forest Hot Tub Soak at Secret Spot
description: Take a break from a busy sightseeing schedule and relax in the tranquil natural environment of the Secret Spot Hot Tubs complex. Surrounded by the Whakarewarewa Forest are a collection of hand-crafted cedar hot tubs in which you can soak your aches and stress away.

ratingNegative.text: THIS IS NOT A THERMAL SPA. Dig deep enough in the FAQ and it states this but as far as I am concerned in Rotorua it is what is expected. Nice setting but not what I went there for.
ratingNegative.author: Kate Osborne

ratingPositive.text: We had a great early evening soak. It was nice to have the drinks delivered to our hot tub for us to enjoy.
ratingPositive.author: charlotte and kerry forsyth

attributiom: Aaron Birch aaronbirch, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Waitomo Glowworm Caves
description: Famous for their abundance of glow worms, extensive underground river system and stunning stalactite and stalagmites formations, a trip to the Waitomo caves is a trip to another world.

ratingNegative.text:
Commercial overkill!
No thanks, I can only recommend the Abbay Caves near Whangarei or the other glowworm caves near Waipu. Both are free and full of glowworms.
ratingNegative.author: Alex Schassada

ratingPositive.text: This tour is definitely worth treating yourself to. It is a very special experience to paddle through the dark cave passages with thousands of tiny glowworms twinkling above you. The cave also features stalactites and stalagmites.
ratingPositive.author: Gu Ki

attribution: Donnie Ray Jones, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Redwoods Treewalk
description: Majestic and magical, the Redwoods Treewalk™ experience is truly a walk to remember. Suspended high above the forest floor, encounter 75-metre-tall redwoods as you walk across eco-suspended bridges and platforms intricately designed to honour and accentuate the stunning natural environment. Regarded by many as one of the best tree top walks in New Zealand. At night, the forest is transformed into a magical wonderland with thousands of lights illuminating the trees and pathways. The Redwoods Nightlights experience is a must-see for visitors to Rotorua.

ratingNegative.text: You need to buy tickets BEFORE you go.  Terribly sign posted so figuring out where to go at night is impossible. I stood in a queue for 30 minutes for the night walk only to be told by someone walking the line that I needed to buy tickets first which was in a completely different queue. I gave up.
ratingNegative.author: Paul

ratingPositive.text: Beautiful tree trail. You should have a head for heights, but it's only 12 meters high at most. There are also beautiful hiking trails on the ground. We took the green trail (2 hours at a relaxed pace). It was very beautiful. But there are also longer trails (8 hours).
ratingPositive.author: S. AJ

title: Glenorchy
description: A small town located at the northern end of Lake Wakatipu, Glenorchy is known for its stunning natural beauty and outdoor activities. It is a popular destination for hiking, fishing, and horseback riding, and is also a gateway to several nearby national parks, including Mount Aspiring National Park and Fiordland National Park.

title: High Country Horses
description: This is your change to not only ride horses in the stunning Glenorchy area, but also to visit the filming location of Isengard and views of the Misty Mountains and many more.

ratingNegative.text: I was really looking forward to this experience, but I didn’t get to ride at all. I was nervous and had trouble getting on the horse. I asked for help, but the staff gave up quickly and just rode off with the rest of the group — leaving me behind. I was stunned and hurt. No second chance, no real support, just left alone after paying over $100.
ratingNegative.author: Vincy Chen

ratingPositive.text: The ride was about and hour and a half threw amazing scenery, it was breathtaking (also you ride by the Misty Mountains from the LOTR). The horses were awesome the whole ride, the trail was smooth and flawless.
ratingPositive.author: Kayla

attribution: Debby the Axe-Thrower (taken on a horseback)

title: Hobbiton Movie Set
description: A must-see for any Lord of the Rings or Hobbit fan, the Hobbiton Movie Set offers a chance to explore the charming village of Hobbiton, complete with hobbit holes, the Green Dragon Inn, and the iconic Party Tree.

ratingNegative.text: Nothing special really, just a movie set of mediocre movie. Not much to see, very expensive; not really worth the visit.
ratingNegative.author: Luckasz Merzenich

ratingPositive.text: If I cOuLd, I wOuLd LiVe HeRe FoReVeR. LoTr Is ThE bEsT ❤❤❤❤
ratingPositive.author: Lord W.

title: Doubtful Sound
description: Less visited than the famous Milford Sound, Doubtful Sound offers a more tranquil and secluded experience. Take a boat tour to explore the fjord's stunning scenery, waterfalls, and wildlife, including dolphins and seals. The journey to Doubtful Sound involves a scenic drive and a ferry crossing, adding to the adventure. Several providers and different tours available.

ratingNegative.text: This trip was way over priced for what you got
ratingNegative.author: Valerie M.

ratingPositive.text: We did the overnight tour. Sean and Juanita were incredible. You are in for a treat if you have them for your crew. The visuals were incredible and the food was absolutely delicious (shout out again to Juanita). We swam, kayaked and Sean even got us under a small waterfall.
ratingPositive.author: Wes Noonan

title: Pouakai Tarns
description: Famous reflective tarns with Mount Taranaki in the background. A moderately challenging 6-8 hour return hike from the Pouakai car park. The track is well marked and maintained, but be prepared for changing weather conditions. Extremely highly frequented track, but if you continue past the tarns onto Henry Peak, you'll get a lot more solitude and even better views.

ratingNegative.text: Overrated and very hard for beginners. We are beginners and it took us 3h for one direction. It was hell, my legs and feet hurt even days after the trip. Dont fall for all other comments. You need very good hiking shoes. There are way better, more beautiful, and easier hiking tracks for taranaki. The little pond was "meh".
ratingNegative.author: Volker Racho

ratingPositive.text: This was my only day to see the mountain so with the rain coming in I couldn't see the whole mountain but I did catch the sunrise which was beautiful! I started my hike at 5am and got to the reflective tarn by 6:50am. You are walking on built steps pretty much the entire time.
ratingPositive.author: Caleb Porco

title: Cape Kidnappers Gannet Colony
description: Home to the largest and most accessible mainland gannet colony in the world, Cape Kidnappers is a must-visit for bird enthusiasts and nature lovers. Sadly, the walkway is closed due to rockfalls, but the guided tours offer even more views and background information.

ratingNegative.text: Just bird
ratingNegative.author: Anonymous Horse

ratingPositive.text: I bet you’ve never seen anything like this before. Had the pleasure of giving tours to black reef, flat rock, and the plateau. Never got tired of the views. Just gotta go in person to see these guys. But really look at the sea of birds. They all got their own thing going on and it’s nice to sit and appreciate what’s happening around you. Like how did I get here? Life really is unpredictable and full of surprises
ratingPositive.author: small bsian

title: Napier
description: Known for its stunning Art Deco architecture, Napier is a charming coastal city that was rebuilt in the Art Deco style after a devastating earthquake in 1931. Take a stroll through the city to admire the unique buildings, visit the local museums, and enjoy the beautiful beaches.
attribution: Robyn Gallagher from Auckland, New Zealand, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Hawke's Bay Wineries
description: Hawke's Bay is one of New Zealand's premier wine regions, known for its excellent red wines, particularly Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. There are plenty of wineries to visit, either self-guided or via tour. Or you do a self-guided bike tour.

title: Shantytown Heritage Park
description: Experience the gold rush era of the 1860s at Shantytown Heritage Park. This recreated 19th-century gold mining town offers a range of activities, including gold panning, steam train rides, and exploring historic buildings.

ratingNegative.text: Shut the place down already or update it and change the ridiculous pricing. the staff need to learn customer service, and would be good if there was a guided tour. Pay extra to gold pan is outrageous and is just a big tourist scam! Will not recommend to anyone
ratingNegative.author: Hitahinga Moaho

ratingPositive.text: Love this place, great for adults and kids.. It's a must do.. So much fun, lots history
ratingPositive.author: Jo Hempseed

title: Carrotland Adventure Park
description: Although there are some interesting tidbits about the history of vegetable farming in the area — it is mainly for seeing all the creepy over-sized vegetable statues. Bonus: Carrot Rocket and Carrot F1 car.

title: Hanmer Springs Thermal Pools & Spa
description: Relax and rejuvenate in the natural hot springs of Hanmer Springs. The thermal pools offer a range of temperatures and settings, from family-friendly pools to more secluded and tranquil spa areas.

ratingNegative.text: Lovely hot springs but very rude lady on front desk today
ratingNegative.author: Emi Frost

ratingPositive.text: Fabulous 👌 …
ratingPositive.author: Frances Roy

title: Cinema Paradiso
description: Iconic cinema in Wanaka showing a mix of mainstream, indie, and foreign films. Sit on comfy couches, a dentist chair or in a VW beetle, order snacks and drinks to your seat, and enjoy the movie in style.

ratingNegative.text: Don't order local hero You won't be able to taste the salmon
ratingNegative.author: Pinting Tang

ratingPositive.text: Great movies, really comfortable seats, staff were very friendly. And the cookie sandwich was sinfully good!
ratingPositive.author: YJ Kwang

title: Waiotapu Thermal Wonderland
description: Waiotapu Thermal Wonderland is a spectacular showcase of New Zealand’s most colourful and unique geothermal elements sculpted by thousands of years of geothermal activity.

ratingNegative.text: If you have never seen a geyser or pool before, don’t start with this one. Extremely disappointing to pay 45$ to see some mud pools and one green pool. Go see the free park in Roturua. You get a better experience at no charge. #newzealandcashgrab
ratingNegative.author: Graham Russel

ratingPositive.text: If you arrive early you can also see the Lady Know Geyser show at 10.15am. Waiptapu Thermal Wonderland is an awesome experience with so much to see. Apart from the main attraction - Champagne Pool, there are Mud Pools, Craters and Waterfalls. You can spend a good 3 hours here easily.
ratingPositive.author: William Lin

title: Tīrau
description: You can't miss Tirau – just look for the large corrugated iron buildings constructed to look like a sheep, dog and ram. This town is a little quirky!

title: Hu Hu Chalet
description: The Chalet is a unique, self contained and modern space right in the heart of Waitomo Village. We have a fridge, microwave, toaster and electric, crockery and all basic kitchen utensils. There is also a free view TV . There is one bedroom upstairs with a queen size bed and all linen is supplied.

ratingNegative.text:
This location looks nice..but...the location is IN the parking lot OF A restaurant. Come and go from people  with a lot of noise at night through behind motel. The WiFi is bad, or say Not functioning. TV works moderately. So no privacy, noise and no WiFi. 
Great bed and bathroom!
ratingNegative.author: Laure

ratingPositive.text: Enjoyed our stay at Huhu Chalet! Love the tall ceilings that look out into the night sky! Quaint cafe next to Huhu Cafe where you can have a drink or two and pop right over to rest for the night! ;)
ratingPositive.author: 2bearbear Tom Lim

title: Tongapōrutu
description: Tongapōrutu is a settlement in northern Taranaki, in the North Island of New Zealand. It is located on State Highway 3 at the mouth of the Tongapōrutu River, 15 kilometres south of Mōkau. Tongapōrutu is well known in New Zealand for its 'Three Sisters' rock formations and its Māori petroglyphs carved into cave rock walls. However, both the Māori rock carvings and the Three Sisters formations are constantly being eroded by the Tasman Sea.
attribution: Takver from Australia, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Hot Water Beach TOP 10 Holiday Park
description: A multi award-winning holiday park, family owned and operated since 2008 and only 700m from the world renown Hot Water Beach. 9 different accommodation options to suit any holiday maker. Year round heated pool complex and a vast array of facilities, events and amenities found nowhere else on the Coromandel.

ratingNegative.text: Worst top 10 I've visited. It was super crowdy and impossible to use the facilites. We were sent to a huge backyard with chemical toilets. Definitely not worth the price.
ratingNegative.author: Federico Ferri

ratingPositive.text: This has got to be up there with one of the best holiday parks we have stayed/ very well organised clean and tidy! Affordable options for larger family’s - play ground was fantastic the whole place was incredible. Pizzas were yummy - coffee great fish and chips were good too! Loved the hot soak area and the plunge into the pool the kids didn’t mind the colder pool it was winter! We stayed in July and took full advantage of their deal and it was great we loved it. Will be back.
ratingPositive.author: Eliza Waszczak

attribution: Takver from Australia, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Tongariro Alpine Crossing
description: The Tongariro Alpine Crossing is heralded as the best one-day trek in New Zealand and is regarded as among the top ten single-day treks in the world. The Tongariro Alpine Crossing is located in the Tongariro National Park - New Zealand's oldest national park and a dual UNESCO World Heritage Site. Important: This track now requires prebooking a slot and a shuttle transport which has to be pre-arranged; and it is even more crowded.
attribution: Jeffrey Pang from Madison, NJ, USA, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Pūtangirua Pinnacles
description: The Pūtangirua Pinnacles (also known colloquially simply as The Pinnacles) are a geological formation and one of New Zealand's best examples of badlands erosion. They consist of a large number of earth pillars or hoodoos located at the head of a valley in the Aorangi Ranges, on the North Island of New Zealand, in the Wellington region.

ratingNegative.text: Carpark full of campers and tents. There is a fire ban yet fires are being lit. The trail is seemingly permanently closed yet people are still doing the trail.
ratingNegative.author: Nathan Smith

ratingPositive.text: Great activity just 2 hours from Wellington. Moderate to difficult walk on the stoney riverbed with heavy erosion.Mostly elevation is minimum except for the last bit. Total about 45mins to 1 hour one way.
ratingPositive.author: Samitha Abeysinghe

title: Wētā Cave
description: The Wētā Cave retail store, guarded by our iconic Cave Trolls, is a must-see for film buffs and lovers of cool stuff. Buy authentic Wētā Workshop designed collectibles, prop replicas, books, jewellery, art prints, gifts, apparel, movie memorabilia and more. Make sure you take a piece of the magic home with you! The Wētā Cave also includes our Wētā Workshop mini museum where you can discover some of the historical props and costumes we’ve made for blockbuster movies.

ratingNegative.text: Very disappointed. The Cave is just a gift shop and the tour costs $20 to look at props and to get an overview on what they do there. Not worth it if you are a fan of any specific film they have made and if you're not looking for a boring 30 min tour. Could have seen/learned it all from behind the scenes films.
ratingNegative.author: Michaela Svagera

ratingPositive.text: Incredible experience, and the staff are all so full of life and brilliance! We walked out feeling inspired to continue our personal creative pursuits. Every time I watch a film now I have a new found respect for the time and work that goes into Weta creations. You won't believe some of the stories you'll learn! Also visited a local bakery before our tour for the yummiest pies and hot chocolate.
ratingPositive.author: JD

attribution: Kristina D. C. Hoeppner (Flickr user 4nitsirk), CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Te Waikoropupu Springs
description: Te Waikoropupū Springs are the largest freshwater springs in New Zealand, the largest cold water springs in the Southern Hemisphere and contain some of the clearest water ever measured.

ratingNegative.text: Very disappointing on a wet day. Rain disturbed the water surface to such an extent that NO spring was visible, and the purported "water clarity" was left to the imagination.
ratingNegative.author: Denis Rainforth

ratingPositive.text: Very beautiful, even if in the rain. We did this loop jn about 20 minutes given the rain. Would have liked it to be longer. Such a beautiful, one of a kind and informative sacred spot to visit.
ratingPositive.author: It's Jess!

title: Wharariki Beach
description: Wharariki Beach is a beach on the Tasman Sea, west of Cape Farewell, the northernmost point of the South Island of New Zealand. The beach is popular for its colony of fur seal pups; during low tide, people have access to the pools where pups play in front of the easternmost of the Archway Islands.

ratingNegative.text: Doesn't have sand
ratingNegative.author: AuroraFlight

ratingPositive.text: Here because the Windows background photo was taken here. The beach itself is large and beautiful in itself. The tide fluctuates greatly, highly recommended to visit at low tide to visit the caves safely. The fluctuating tide also causes stunning sand patterns on the beach.
ratingPositive.author: Tc203

title: Farewell Spit
description: Farewell Spit stretches 34km long, making it one of the longest natural sandspits in the world. A wetland of international importance, it has been a bird sanctuary since the 1930’s and provides a home for over 90 bird species. Bar tailed godwits, knots, curlews, whimbrels and turnstones fly around 12,000 kilometres every northern hemisphere autumn to spend the summer here in the south. The spit also has a gannet colony.

ratingNegative.text: Awesome piece of NZ well worth a visit by anyone who loves history, wildlife and unique landscapes. Unfortunately you can only walk about 5kms into the spit as it is protected reserve. You have to pay and be a part of an authorised tour to see the whole spit. On this occasion I did the public walk. Beware of quick sand between the coasts! I sank to my knees stepping in a puddle of sand. Will definitely do the paid tour next time. Lots of wildlife. Take some water.
ratingNegative.author: M N Scott

ratingPositive.text: It’s a very interesting place, the desert part is a very different then the surroundings areas. you wouldn’t believe that you’re in New zealand. it’s a very long walk so you’ll definitely need some food and water with you. you cannot go to the whole spit part because it’s protected, but you can take tours if you want to see the whole spit. it can be very hot around December and January (got sunburned) will definitely go there again by taking tours.
ratingPositive.author: harjeet Nz

title: Tama Lakes
description: Since the Tongariro Crossing is extremely (!) crowded, this walk is a great alternative, offering even better views of Mount Doom, while being easily accessible and much less crowded. To break the fourth wall — I did both and I'd rather do this walk again.

title: Cape Reinga
description: Northernmost tip of New Zealand, where the Tasman Sea meets the Pacific Ocean. A culturally significant site for the Māori people, who believe it is the point where spirits depart for the afterlife. The lighthouse and surrounding area offer stunning views and a sense of tranquility. However, the more amazing walks branch off to the west or east, and offer outstanding views of the dramatic coast.

title: Te Paki sand dunes
description: Giant sanddunes that do not really fit into the surrounding landscapes. They can be explored by foot, or you can go sandboarding on them.
attribution: Debby the Axe-Thrower | Model: Lukasz Merzenich

title: Mangawhai Heads Walkway
description: Scenic walkway along the cliffs, one of North Island's most scenic short walkways. If the tides permit, you can return via the beach.

title: Clay Cliffs Omarama
description: A lesser known, hidden gem — impressive clay pinnacles with narrow ravines.

title: Mount Cook Village
description: Mount Cook Village is a small settlement in the South Island of New Zealand, located within the Aoraki/Mount Cook National Park. It serves as a base for visitors exploring the surrounding alpine environment, including Aoraki/Mount Cook, the highest peak in New Zealand. The village offers various accommodations, dining options, and outdoor activities such as hiking, mountaineering, and scenic flights. Apart from the obligatory Hooker Valley Track (note the closures!), there are other highly recommended walks, such as the climb up to the Mueller Hut or the Tasman Lake and River Track.

title: Crown Range Road
description: The Crown Range Road is the highest main road in New Zealand, reaching an elevation of 1,121 meters at the Crown Saddle. The road connects the towns of Queenstown and Wanaka, offering stunning views of the surrounding mountains and valleys. The road is a popular route for tourists and locals alike, with several lookout points and picnic areas along the way. However, the road can be challenging to drive, with steep inclines and sharp turns, so caution is advised.

ratingPositive.text: Crown range summit has a nice view due to its high altitude. Very nice view.
ratingPositive.author: FF2030

ratingNegative.text: the waiter doesn't speak English, we were served the wrong wines, and the oysters aren't very good.
ratingNegative.author: Lucien Fonteneau

title: Slope Point
description: Slope Point is the southernmost point of the South Island of New Zealand. It is located in the Catlins region, known for its rugged coastline, dense forests, and diverse wildlife. The area around Slope Point is characterized by rolling hills, farmland, and native bush. A short walk from the car park leads to a viewpoint marked by a signpost indicating the distances to various locations around the world. The windswept landscape and panoramic views make Slope Point a popular destination for visitors seeking to experience the remote beauty of New Zealand's southernmost tip. But beware — it is very windy here!

title: Roaring Bay Penguin Colony
description: The only mainland yellow-eyed penguin colony in the world, located in a protected reserve. Visitors can observe these rare and endangered birds in their natural habitat from a viewing platform, without disturbing them. The colony is home to several breeding pairs of yellow-eyed penguins, as well as other seabirds such as gannets and shags. The area around Roaring Bay is also known for its scenic coastal views and walking trails.

ratingPositive.text: At 6:20 pm on August 23, 2025, I saw a yellow-eyed penguin coming ashore from the sea and returning home!
ratingPositive.author: pound chen

ratingNegative.text: We haven't seen any. We read that only one pair of penguins living there.
ratingNegative.author: Bernadett Halasi

title: Bluff
description: Bluff is a town located at the southern tip of New Zealand's South Island. It is known for its rich maritime history, stunning coastal scenery, and as the gateway to Stewart Island. The town is famous for its oysters, which are considered some of the best in the world. Visitors can explore the Bluff Maritime Museum, take a scenic drive along the Bluff Hill Lookout, or enjoy fresh seafood at local restaurants.

title: Steampunk HQ
description: Steampunk HQ is an interactive art gallery and museum located in Oamaru, New Zealand. The gallery features a collection of steampunk-inspired art and sculptures, as well as interactive exhibits that allow visitors to experience the steampunk aesthetic. The gallery is housed in a former Victorian-era building, which has been transformed into a steampunk wonderland.

ratingPositive.text: This was such a highlight of my road trip up the east coast. I decided to randomly stop and check it out and it was such a creative and fun place to visit. So many interactive and unique exhibits and well worth the visit. Very highly recommend.
ratingPositive.author: Katie M

ratingNegative.text: Staff did not greet us when we walked in and had to excuse ourselves to get service. Staff sniggered when we paid and went to walk into the museum. Unfortunately would not go back due to the terrible customer service.
ratingNegative.author: Melissa mc

title: Moeraki Boulders Beach
description: Picturesque beach featuring sphere-shaped boulders on the sand, plus a nearby cafe & sunrise views.

title: Mount Sunday / Edoras
description: Scenic mountain with hiking trails, rock formations, and panoramic views, known for its role as Edoras in the Lord of the Rings films. Accesible with tours from Christchurch, or via a bumpy (but easily drivable) road by car.

title: Castle Hill
description: Limestone rock formations, popular for bouldering and rock climbing, with walking trails and picnic areas.

ratingNegative.text: don't go it sux
ratingNegative.author: Barnaby Bruce

ratingPositive.text: If you have the time, is worth stopping for some photos. Nice landscape with huge rocks of different shape. Is worth the drive all the way from Christchurch.
ratingPositive.author: Boo Boo

title: Arthurs Pass
description: Picturesque mountain village in the Southern Alps, known for hiking trails, wildlife, and stunning alpine scenery. Easiest access to see Kea's taking apart cars.

title: Queenstown
description: Adventure capital of New Zealand, offering a range of outdoor activities such as bungee jumping, skydiving, jet boating, and skiing. The town is also known for its stunning scenery, with the surrounding mountains and Lake Wakatipu providing a picturesque backdrop. Visitors can explore the town's vibrant nightlife, enjoy local cuisine at restaurants and cafes, or take a scenic cruise on the lake. Queenstown is a popular destination for tourists seeking both adventure and relaxation. It is also known for its Fergburger, although that has gotten quite some competition in recent years.
attribution: Lawrence Murray from Perth, Australia, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

title: Pub on Wharf
description: The Pub on Wharf is a popular waterfront restaurant and bar located in the heart of Queenstown, New Zealand. Known for its stunning views of Lake Wakatipu and the surrounding mountains, the pub offers a relaxed atmosphere where visitors can enjoy a variety of food and drinks. The menu features a range of options, including classic pub fare, seafood dishes, and local specialties. The Pub on Wharf is also known for its extensive selection of craft beers and wines, making it a favorite spot for both locals and tourists looking to unwind after a day of adventure in Queenstown. If you don't want to wait in line for the (overrated) Fergburger, this is a viable option.

ratingPositive.text: I may or may not have stayed here several times during my 2013 visit, including New Year's Eve. I most certainly have not drunk too much with an Australian couple.
ratingPositive.author: Lukasz Merzenich

ratingNegative.text: Had one Golden Lager pint here. Cost about $15 and it wasn’t close to being cold. ! Total waste of money, can’t even serve a cold beer in a cold climate.
ratingNegative.author: Harry

title: Baldwin Street
description: The steepest residential street in the world, located in Dunedin, New Zealand. The street has a gradient of 35%, making it a popular tourist attraction and a challenge for runners and cyclists.

title: Akaroa
description: A charming French-inspired town located on the Banks Peninsula, known for its beautiful harbor, historic architecture, and wildlife encounters. Visitors can explore the town's quaint streets, enjoy local cuisine at cafes and restaurants, and take boat tours to see dolphins, penguins, and seals.

title: Whale Watch Kaikōura
description: Whale Watch Kaikōura offers boat tours to see sperm whales, dolphins, and other marine life in their natural habitat. The tours are led by experienced guides who provide information about the animals and their behavior. Imporant: There is a very high possibility of getting sea-sick, even if you never get sea-sick.

ratingPositive.text: Incredible experience. Comfortable boat ride out that only took about 10 minutes. We saw 3 whales and lots of dolphins and seals. Great information from the staff and documentary about the wildlife. Highly recommend to all ages.
ratingPositive.author: Iverlene F

ratingNegative.text: A Money making excercise!!
ratingNegative.author: jonjo Record

title: Gisborne
description: Gisborne is a city located on the east coast of New Zealand's North Island. It is known for its beautiful beaches, rich Maori culture, and as the first city in the world to see the sunrise each day.

title: Lake Waikaremoana
description: Lake Waikaremoana is a stunning lake located in the Te Urewera region of New Zealand's North Island. The lake is surrounded by lush native forest and offers a range of outdoor activities, including hiking, fishing, and kayaking. Access is via an unsealed road, but incrredibly scenic. One of the most remote areas in the North Island.

title: Lake Daniell
description: Lake Daniell is a beautiful alpine lake located in the West Coast region of New Zealand's South Island. The lake is surrounded by native forest and offers a range of outdoor activities, including hiking, fishing, and camping. The lake is accessible via a short walk from the car park, making it a popular destination for day trips and overnight camping.

title: Cape Foulwind
description: Cape Foulwind is a scenic headland located on the West Coast of New Zealand's South Island. The cape is known for its rugged coastline, stunning views, and a colony of New Zealand fur seals. Visitors can take a short walk to the Cape Foulwind Lighthouse, which offers panoramic views of the Tasman Sea and the surrounding area. The cape is also home to several walking trails, including the popular Cape Foulwind Walkway, which takes visitors along the coastline and through native bush.

ratingPositive.text: Cape Foulwind Lighthouse offers stunning coastal views, especially at sunset. It’s a peaceful spot for walk, with seals nearby and fascinating history. A must visit if you’re in Westport!
ratingPositive.author: jain paul

ratingNegative.text: Bit disappointing
ratingNegative.author: Glenys Fentonr

title: Pancake Rocks
description: The Pancake Rocks and Blowholes at Punakaiki on the West Coast of New Zealand's South Island are a natural wonder. The rocks are made of layers of limestone that have been eroded by the sea, creating a unique pancake-like appearance. The blowholes are formed when waves crash into the rocks, forcing water and air through narrow openings and creating impressive spouts of water. The area is a popular tourist destination, with walking trails and viewing platforms that offer stunning views of the rocks and blowholes.

ratingPositive.text: Incredible experience! The rock formations are truly unique, and the blowholes were amazing to watch, especially during high tide. The walking track is easy and offers stunning coastal views throughout. A must-visit spot if you’re in the area!
ratingPositive.author: Arjun Bhandari

ratingNegative.text: This is the sight that every tourist wants to see, so it is very crowded
ratingNegative.author: Ruedi Vogt

title: Lake Brunner
description: Lake Brunner is a picturesque lake located on the West Coast of New Zealand's South Island. The lake is surrounded by native forest and offers a range of outdoor activities, including fishing, boating, and hiking. The lake is known for its clear waters and abundant trout population, making it a popular destination for anglers. Visitors can also explore the nearby walking trails, which offer stunning views of the lake and surrounding mountains.
attribution: Lukasz Merzenich, taken on Mt Te Kinga

title: Okarito Lagoon & Beach
description: Okarito Lagoon is a stunning coastal lagoon located on the West Coast of New Zealand's South Island. The lagoon is known for its rich biodiversity, including a variety of bird species such as the rare white heron (kotuku). Visitors can explore the lagoon by kayak or take a guided tour to learn about the area's unique ecology and Maori history. The surrounding area also offers several walking trails, including the walk to Three Mile Lagoon if tides permit, where you can see all the way to Mt Cook.
attribution: Debby the Axe-Thrower (taken on the walk to Three Mile Lagoon)

title: Lake Matheson
description: Lake Matheson is a picturesque lake located near Fox Glacier on the West Coast of New Zealand's South Island. The lake is known for its stunning reflections of the surrounding mountains, including Aoraki/Mount Cook and Mount Tasman. Visitors can take a short walk around the lake, which offers several viewing points for photography and birdwatching. The area is also home to a variety of native flora and fauna, making it a popular destination for nature lovers.

ratingPositive.text: Very nice walk around the lake. It’ll cost you about 1,5 hours in total. And if you’re lucky you can make the perfect reflection picture. I was not 😅 But still enjoyed this walk very much. The path is just wonderful.
ratingPositive.author: Femke Czech

ratingNegative.text: Completely over crowded with tourist buses. Just heaps of people yelling and all scrambling for the spots on the viewing platform. The view of the mountains is good though. Just go to the carpark get your photos then leave. Dont do the walk its not worth the lake at all.
ratingNegative.author: P Kelly

title: Isthmus Peak
description: Isthmus Peak is a prominent mountain located in the Southern Alps of New Zealand's South Island. It is a steep hike, but the views are amazing, and you're guaranteed to have less crowds than on the crowded Roy's Peak, and the views are even more specially since it's perched between two lakes.

title: Rob Roy Glacier Track
description: The Rob Roy Glacier Track is a popular hiking trail located in the Mountains of New Zealand's South Island. The track offers stunning views of the Rob Roy Glacier, as well as the surrounding mountains and valleys. The hike is relatively short, taking around 3-4 hours round trip, but it is steep in places and requires a good level of fitness. Rough gravel road to the car park, but tourists drive there even with large campervans.

title: Diamond Lake Hiking Tracks
description: Diamond Lake is a beautiful alpine lake located in the Otago region of New Zealand's South Island. The lake is surrounded by native forest and offers a range of hiking trails, including the popular Diamond Lake Loop Track. The loop track is a moderate hike that takes around 2-3 hours to complete and offers stunning views of the lake and surrounding mountains. The area is also home to a variety of native flora and fauna, making it a popular destination for nature lovers.
